TITLE_DISCLAIM_1:
Super Mario Bros Remastered is a not-for-profit fangame, and should never ever be sold.

It does not serve as a substitute to playing any of the original games.

Super Mario Bros 1 and 2, can be played now on Nintendo Switch through Nintendo Switch Online.
TITLE_DISCLAIM_2:
Super Mario Bros Remastered. Its developer, and all related entities are not affiliated with or endorsed by Nintendo. Resources which appear in this game are used for the purpose of fair use, with transformative applications being applied.

This game merely serves as a love letter to the original game, made by a passionate fan :)
CAMPAIGN_SMBLL: Super Mario Bros. The Lost Levels
CAMPAIGN_SMBANN: All Night Nippon: Super Mario Bros.
DIFFI_PHYSICS_STYLE_WARNING:
This game was designed with the modern physics style in mind. Some levels and challenges may be harder, or even impossible with the classic physics. 
 
you have been warned.
DESC_DMG_STYLE_0: When taking damage, revert to "Small" state.
DESC_DMG_STYLE_1: When taking damage, revert to "Big" state, if "Fire".
DESC_FLAG_0: No flags, simply pass a certain point within a level, classic experience.
DESC_FLAG_1: Checkpoint flags are present within levels, modern experience
DESC_FLAG_2: Checkpoint flags now give you a mushroom if needed, when activated.
DESC_EXTRA_CHECK_0: There are no extra checkpoints in levels.
DESC_EXTRA_CHECK_1: Checkpoints have been added to levels, that didnt have them.
DESC_FLAG_LIVES_0: Flagpoles will not give an extra life when touching the top, classic experience.
DESC_FLAG_LIVES_1: Flagpoles will give an extra life if touching the top, modern experience
DESC_GAME_OVER_0: When reaching a Game Over, go back to the start of the world.
DESC_GAME_OVER_1: When reaching a Game Over, go back to the start of the level.
DESC_GAME_OVER_2: When reaching a Game Over, go back to the start of the game.
DESC_LEVEL_DESIGN_0: Level design is the same as the original, can be unfair at times.
DESC_LEVEL_DESIGN_1: Level design is adjusted to be much fairer.
DESC_TIME_0: There is no time limit in levels.
DESC_TIME_1: There is a time limit in all levels.
DESC_TIME_2: There is a time limit in all levels, however each unit is one second long.
DESC_BACKSCROLL_0: You cannot move backwards in levels (unless a custom level allows it), Intended Experience
DESC_BACKSCROLL_1: You can move backwards in all levels (unless a custom level prevents it)
DESC_LAKITU_0: Lakitu will throw spinies straight upwards, exactly like in the original games. (This was due to a bug.)
DESC_LAKITU_1: Lakitu will throw spinies diagonally up, which was the originally intended behaviour.
DESC_SPINY_0: Spinies are unable to be defeated with a bump from below, matching their original behaviour.
DESC_SPINY_1: Spinies are capable of being defeated with a bump from below, much like their modern appearances.
DESC_HAMMER_BRO_0: Hammer Bros. will throw hammers that have slower, floatier physics more aggressively, but don't charge for longer like they do originally.
DESC_HAMMER_BRO_1: Hammer Bros. will throw hammers that have faster, heavier physics at a more subdued rate, but will rush down the player faster.
DESC_BOWSER_0: Bowser will behave as he originally did, throwing flurries of hammers and chasing you down in desperation when you get past him.
DESC_BOWSER_1: Bowser will behave as he does normally, with spaced out hammer throws without chasing you down when getting past him.
DESC_PHYSICS_0: The classic physics: Recreated. Unintended Experience.
DESC_PHYSICS_1: Modernized and generally better feeling physics, The Intended Experience.
CUTSCENE_CASTLE_TOAD_2: But our princess is in another castle!
CUTSCENE_CASTLE_PEACH_3: We present you a new quest.
CUTSCENE_CASTLE_PEACH_4: Extra content has been unlocked! Enjoy!
CUTSCENE_MARATHON_PEACH_3: That's a new best! Great job!
DELETION_WARNING: Warning! This will permanently delete data!
EDITOR_DELETION_DESCRIPTION:
This will permanently wipe your level!

Are you sure you want to proceed?
GUIDE_INTRO_TEXT:
Welcome to the level editor! 
 
Although this may seem a bit complex, the editor itself, is quite simple to understand. It's not as polished or seamless as Super Mario Maker, but it gets the job done, and can actually do some extra things aswell if you know what you're doing! 
Feel free to take your time, reading through all the features the editor has to offer. 
 
If you ever need to open this guide again, simply press this icon in the tile menu.
GUIDE_CONTROL_SEC1_TEXT: To place tiles, simply use left click, you can hold down left click, and drag the mouse around, to use it as a brush. to remove tiles, simply use right click.
GUIDE_CONTROL_SEC2_TEXT: You can move the camera around using WASD, and speed up the movement of it by holding down SHIFT.
GUIDE_CONTROL_SEC3_TEXT:
To playtest your level, simply press ENTER, To return to the editor, press Enter Again. 
 
If you want to move the players starting position, simply press SHIFT + MIDDLE CLICK Or press M.
GUIDE_CONTROL_SEC4_TEXT: In the top left of the screen, you can see a small cogwheel icon, if you click it, it will reveal lots of options to you, which can help in making / testing levels. These include completely resetting a level, undo, redo, toggling the tile grid, toggling a player trail, and showing gizmos while playtesting a level, to better debug issues.
GUIDE_TILEMEN_TEXT:
When pressing E, you can open up the tile menu! this is the main place where you will be choosing which objects to place in your level. It should all be fairly basic, but theres a few hidden features you may not know about. 
 
If an option in the menu has a small + in the corner, it means it contains multiple different tiles within. Use the scroll wheel or R/T keys when hovering over it, to choose other tiles inside. 
 
When hovering over an option, if the nametag contains '...' at the bottom, it has a readable description, which you can view by holding SHIFT. This can provide useful context on certain objects, and how to use them.
GUIDE_TILEMOD_TEXT: YOU CAN EDIT THE PROPERTIES OF VARIOUS OBJECTS, BY SHIFT + LEFT CLICKING THEM. THIS WILL OPEN UP A MENU, WHICH ALLOWS YOU TO EDIT ALL THE VARIOUS PROPERTIES AVAILABLE, TO CLOSE THE MENU SIMPLY PRESS E.
GUIDE_MASSPL_TEXT: IF YOU NEED TO PLACE OUT OR REMOVE A LARGE AREA OF A SINGLE OBJECT, YOU CAN DO SO, BY SIMPLY HOLDING DOWN CTRL, AND DRAGGING OUT AN AREA USING EITHER LEFT OR RIGHT CLICK, TO PLACE OR REMOVE AN AREA QUICKLY.
GUIDE_LAYERS_TEXT:
Each Level has up to 5 layers, which you can use to place anything inside of. Layers are ordered from front-most to back-most (Layer 1 is Front, Layer 5 is Back). You can change layers by using the Page UP and Page DOWN keys, or by using CTRL+UP or CTRL+DOWN Arrows. 
 
Some objects take advantage of the layers, such as with the Track Rider object, which will attach any object that is placed either ontop of it, or behind it, on a different layer. Some Gizmos which detect certain objects may also only detect objects which are on the same layer as it, allowing you to easily filter certain objects.
GUIDE_PIPES_TEXT:
Pipes are a bit tricky to understand, however they can be fairly simple once you grasp the main ideas of how they work. 
 
To start, Pipes ARE NOT 'All-in-one' objects like they are in Mario Maker. Pipes are instead defined by their tiles, and the objects placed near them. 
 
In the tile menu, you can see LOTS of different pipe tiles you can place down, however these themselves do not create a 'Pipe' and are purely visual. To create a proper 'Pipe' you can enter, you will need a 'Pipe Area' object, which you can place somewhere to make that area behave like a pipe. This means that you can create a pipe anywhere, without actually needing to place down the tiles. 
 
You can link two pipes together using their 'IDs', having a Pipe with an ID of 1 will ALWAYS go to another pipe, with the same ID. 
 
HOWEVER, it is important to note, that pipes that can be exited from, MUST be set to be 'Exit Only'. If you want to make a pipe exit AND enterable, simply place another PipeArea object, in a different layer.
GUIDE_WARPS_TEXT:
When dealing with warping between rooms, its important to make sure that the objects you want to use, are sync'd up via the same channel. 
 
Doors and Pipes use seperate channels, and can only be connected to objects of the same type (Pipes cannot be connected to doors, and vice versa)
GUIDE_MULTSEL_TEXT:
You can select multiple objects on a single layer at once, to either cut, copy, or save as a blueprint. 
 
To do so, simply hold down Q and Left Click, and drag out the area you want to select. 
 
Once done so, the selected area will be highlighted in yellow, and you can then either copy, cut or save, depending on which keys you press. 
 
CTRL+C: Copy 
CTRL+X: Cut 
CTRL+S: Save as blueprint. 
 
When an area has been either cut or copied, it will be saved to the clipboard, allowing you to paste it in, using CTRL+V. 
 
If you choose to save it as a blueprint, a popup window will show, allowing you to name your file, which can then be found in the blueprints tab, of the tile menu.
GUIDE_BLUPRNT_TEXT:
Blueprints allow you to easily save schematics of what you have built, to allow you to easily re-use them or share designs with others. 
 
When saving a blueprint, it gets saved as a .mbp file, which you can then share with others, to allow them to easily use your designs in their levels. 
 
Blueprints also save any connections to other objects in that blueprint, so feel free to use them as an easy way, to create powerful, modular systems for your levels!
GUIDE_GIZMO_TEXT:
Gizmos are powerful objects which allow you make levels more dynamic, interactive and fun. They're essentially a collection of small objects, that you can connect to each other, using a basic 'Input Output' system. 
 
You can start a connection through the modifier menu of the object, and then clicking the + button, next to its 'Connections', from there, you can just click on whatever it is you want to connect it to. 
 
NOTE: its important to know that the direction you connect things is important. Connecting Object 1 to Object 2, does NOT mean that Object 2 is connected back to Object 1, that is a seperate connection you would have to make. 
 
Gizmos can either turn on or off, or emit a pulse, which is a small one-off signal. Depending on what recieves these signals, and what type it is, different things will happen! 
 
Other 'Non-Gizmo' objects can be connected too, and can have extra functionality, when connected, so go explore and find out whats possible!
